qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: Right now, I use it mostly for WhatsApp to talk to my sister and some voice calls. I’m trying to learn how to browse for recipes and home tips on YouTube. I used to use more apps on my older phone, but this one is slow.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: I rarely share this phone—it’s already second-hand and a bit delicate. Only my daughter sometimes uses it to help me with apps.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: WhatsApp and YouTube for now. I don’t know much about what apps collect. My daughter says, ‘Amma, don't click on strange messages.’

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like access to location or contacts, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: To be honest, I didn’t even notice permissions before. Now I look, but I don’t understand everything, so I just press ‘Allow’ if the app is from a known place.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: I trust the apps my daughter or relatives use. I haven’t tried anything alone yet.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Yes, I delete old messages and group forwards because my phone has low storage space. I’ve also deleted apps that keep sending pop-ups.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I haven’t repaired this phone yet, but I would go to the local mobile shop. I’ll ask my husband to come with me because I don’t feel confident going alone with this phone.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, many times. My daughter or niece helps. I ask them to do it while I watch so I can learn, but sometimes they’re too fast!

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: I trust family members. If I have to send something personal, I prefer to talk directly or send via WhatsApp to my husband or sister.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Not yet, but I’ve seen my niece do that with her friends. It’s interesting. I might start if needed.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: Not yet. I’m the one asking for help now. Maybe one day I can help others too.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera or location?
qa.answer: No, but I want to learn this. My daughter said she’ll show me in settings.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I get scared and stop using it. Once, I even deleted the app just to be safe.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I think it helps in connecting to people, but I didn’t know it might keep that data. That worries me.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, I’m afraid they might check my photos or messages. I try to delete things before giving them, or ask my daughter to do it.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: Not yet. But if that happens, I would feel very uncomfortable.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: Yes, my daughter set a PIN for me. I know how to use it now.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I really don’t know. I just use the ones my family uses.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: My daughter, niece, or sometimes my husband. I also watch YouTube if it’s a simple thing.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my family warns me about scams and tells me to ignore strange calls or messages.

scenarios.Broken Phone: If this phone breaks, I’ll delete my WhatsApp messages and photos, then give it to the repair shop. I will ask someone to come with me because I don’t trust the shop fully.
scenarios.Sharing a Phone with Family: Only my daughter uses it, and I don’t have anything secret. But I still close my chats before handing them over.
scenarios.Installing a New App: If the app asks for too many permissions, I leave it. I ask my daughter if she says it’s safe, only then do I install.
scenarios.Helping an Elderly Relative: I’m still learning myself, but if my aunt asks, I’ll try or ask someone younger in the house to help her.
scenarios.Using a Borrowed Phone: I won’t touch anything extra. If something opens by mistake, I close it immediately. I believe in privacy.
scenarios.Selling or Giving Away a Phone: Before giving, I will delete everything I can. But for full formatting, I’ll ask my daughter to do it.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: This happened once—I deleted photos, but later they were still in some Google thing. I was confused. Now I know a bit about cloud backup.
scenarios.Using Free Public WiFi: I don’t use free WiFi. My son says it’s risky. I stick to mobile data even if it’s slow.
scenarios.Receiving a lottery: No, I would never give my details. I already got such a call and blocked the number. It felt fake.
scenarios.Sharing account details: If a close friend is in trouble, I’ll ask my daughter to help transfer money. I don’t do it alone yet.
